study_identification.title: Improving the predictive potential of diffusion MRI in schizophrenia using normative models -Towards subject-level classification

clarity_of_research_objectives.reason: The research objectives are clearly stated. The study aims to evaluate the predictive power of features derived from a normative modeling approach for classifying individuals with schizophrenia versus healthy controls, using diffusion MRI data. The authors explicitly state their motivation to 'improve the characterization of the schizophrenia group as a whole by assuming that common abnormalities may occur in spatially distinct regions across subjects' and test 'whether these profiles provide an improved characterization of the group, compared to the raw values.' The PICO elements are identifiable: Population (individuals with schizophrenia and healthy controls), Intervention (normative modeling applied to dMRI), Comparator (raw dMRI values, case-control approaches), and Outcome (individual-level deviation patterns, predictive performance for classification).
clarity_of_research_objectives.supporting_text: Here, our motivation is to improve the characterization of the schizophrenia group as a whole by assuming that common abnormalities (e.g., decreased FA/FAt, increased FW) may occur in spatially distinct regions across subjects. By using the features obtained from the normative model in a classification scheme, we test whether these profiles provide an improved characterization of the group, compared to the raw values.

Brain measures used include standard (FA) and advanced (FAt, FW from free-water imaging) dMRI measures in 18 white matter regions (17 tracts + white matter skeleton). Methods for quantifying individual-level deviations are detailed: age- and sex-adjusted z-scores calculated using the Nadaraya-Watson estimator with Gaussian kernel. details_of_data_preprocessing.reason: The neuroimaging data preprocessing procedures are clearly described. Preprocessing software is specified: FSL's DTIFIT for DTI model fitting, ANTs registration for spatial normalization. Specific preprocessing steps are detailed: (1) data were fitted to DTI model to derive FA; (2) data were fitted to two-compartment free-water imaging model using regularized nonlinear fit to estimate FW and FAt; (3) white matter ROIs were defined using IIT Human Brain probabilistic white matter fiber tract atlas v.4.1 with threshold of 0.25; (4) FA images were registered to IIT FA template using ANTs; (5) transformation was applied to other diffusion measures; (6) mean FA, FAt, and FW were computed across voxels in each tract. Quality control is addressed through harmonization procedures. Reference is made to Cetin-Karayumak et al. (2020) for complete preprocessing protocol details.
details_of_data_preprocessing.supporting_text: The harmonized data were fitted using FSL's DTIFIT (Behrens et al., 2003) to the DTI model, from which FA was derived. The data were also fitted to the two-compartments Free-water imaging model (including a free-water compartment and a tissue compartment) using a regularized nonlinear fit (Pasternak et al., 2009). [...] To define white matter regions of interest (ROIs) we used the IIT Human Brain probabilistic white matter fiber tract ROIs atlas v. 4.1 (Varentsova, Zhang, & Arfanakis, 2014) with a threshold of 0.25, resulting in a total of 17 white matter fiber tract ROIs. The FA image of each subject was registered to the FA IIT template using ANTs registration (Avants et al., 2011), and this transformation was applied to the other diffusion measures (FAt, FW).

The partition composition is explicitly detailed: seven subsets comprised of 51 controls and 60 schizophrenia subjects, two subsets comprised of 52 controls and 60 schizophrenia subjects, and one subset comprised of 51 controls and 61 schizophrenia subjects. In each cross-validation round, one of 10 subsets served as test set while the other 9 served as training set. Importantly, measures to prevent data leakage are confirmed: 'in each cross-validation, the normative range, as well as the choice of a bandwidth, were estimated using only the healthy control subjects that belonged to the corresponding training set. interpretation_specific_to_normative_mod.reason: The interpretation of individual-level deviation patterns and their clinical significance is appropriately discussed. The meaning of individual-level deviation scores is clearly explained: z-scores represent deviations from age- and sex-adjusted normative range; extreme deviations (|z|>2.999) defined as abnormal. Clinical thresholds and decision criteria are discussed: the study found that the 'significant range' for discrimination (-3.36<z<-0.6 for FA) only partially overlaps with the 'abnormal' threshold, with most discriminative values within the 'normal' range (|z|<2.999). Differences and advantages compared to traditional case-control studies are extensively discussed: normative modeling allows for individual-level inferences and accounts for heterogeneity in abnormality location, unlike case-control approaches that assume consistent patterns. Prospects for clinical application are realistically discussed: authors acknowledge limitations ('acceptable discrimination' level, not comparable to clinical diagnosis) while suggesting this could be 'an early step in the development of a classification scheme.'
interpretation_specific_to_normative_mod.supporting_text: We also find that extreme deviations from the normative model are not found in a sufficient number of individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia, and, accordingly, summary measures based on extreme deviations are less efficient diagnostic measures. Indeed, the z-distribution analysis identified that the range of z-scores that best discriminates the individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia from controls is bounded and does not include the most extreme range of z-scores. [...] We emphasize that as the diagnosis of schizophrenia relies upon identifying several different combinations of clinical symptoms and behavioral signs through an interview with a medical specialist, we do not expect that combining the normative modeling approach with classification would yield a performance that is comparable to clinical diagnosis. Rather, our aim is to provide new information about white matter abnormalities in schizophrenia using the combination of the two approaches, which may be proven useful in the future design of classification schemes

additional_comments.additional_comments: This study represents a methodologically rigorous application of normative modeling to diffusion MRI in schizophrenia. Strengths include: (1) Large multi-site sample with robust harmonization procedures; (2) Clear mathematical framework with detailed algorithms; (3) Novel approach to age/sex adjustment using nonparametric Nadaraya-Watson estimator with leave-one-out bandwidth selection; (4) Comparison of multiple dMRI measures (FA, FAt, FW) demonstrating added value of free-water imaging; (5) Proper cross-validation preventing data leakage. Limitations acknowledged by authors include: lack of external validation, clinical heterogeneity not fully characterized, data not acquired with state-of-the-art protocols, no investigation of clinical symptom relationships. The study makes important contributions to understanding that (a) extreme deviations may not be optimal features for prediction, and (b) the complete distribution of subtle deviations across multiple regions and measures provides better characterization than thresholded abnormality counts. The finding that discriminative z-scores fall within the 'normal' range challenges conventional normative modeling interpretation. Sex differences in predictive features (FW more important in females, FAt in males) warrant further investigation.
